title: Computation of the MLE for bivariate interval censored data
segmentation: OK, so I'm going to talk about the computation of the Emily for bivariate.
Interval censored data and I'll first show an example of what type of data is.

So, for example, suppose that we want to estimate a joint distribution of variables X&Y, where you can think of, for example, X being the time of HIV infection of a person, and why being the time at which the person gets full blown aids.
So when the person really becomes sick.
So then a person would have a realization in the plane like that.
They're all above the diagonal because you get aids after HIV.
Um?
I know the trouble is that X&Y can be interval censored, that in reality we often do not observe the realization this dot here that I've shown in the.
But instead, maybe this person has done two HIV tests at these time points.
And then because the person was infected here at this point, the first Test will be negative and the 2nd test will be positive and the information that we get is that the per.
And was infected somewhere in between, but we don't know exactly when it happened.
Similarly for 8.
A person is defined to have eight when you have when you satisfy certain conditions like your CD, 4 count is low and you have so many infections and that kind of thing.
So maybe this person had two doctors visits at the first one he or she did not satisfy the conditions and at the second one.
He or she did so we know that AIDS occurs sometime between those time points.
So instead of this.
Realization here.
This dot we observe a rectangle that is known to contain this unobservable realization.
And our goal is and is well, this rectangle I call an observation rectangle or an observed set.
An our goal is to estimate the joint distribution of X&Y based on any of those rectangles corresponding to N people.
And it doesn't have to be related to HIV or AIDS.
You can also think, for example, of cancer patients and maybe the time.
At which the cancer must estimate testa sizes so spreads in the body and maybe some blood measure that you're interested in and you want to look at the relationship of those or in reliability.
Theory you could look at lifetimes of machines and things like that.
OK, so well.
We look at the nonparametric maximum likelihood estimator.
Yes.
Um, no.
No, but the smaller the better.
Yes, yes.
Um?

OK, so we look at a nonparametric maximum likelihood estimator, an well this estimator maximizes this log likelihood function over the set of all possible bivariate distribution functions that I called the script F. And the log likelihood function is simply the sum of the log of the probability masses in each of these rectangles under distribution F. No, I don't.
I haven't put it here, but you could in the HIV if you carry that through, you would probably if you get any mass below the diagonal I would later put that on top of it, yeah?
But this is the general case where I don't take that into account.
Well, the easiest way to think about this, Emily, I find, is to imagine that you have probability mass one.
That we want to distribute over this plane in order to make this log likelihood function as large as possible.
And then when.
Think of it like that.

You can, for example, see immediately that you will never put any mass here, for example, because you lose some of your mass, but it doesn't contribute to the log likelihood at all, because it doesn't fall in any of the rectangles.
So it's Beth.
To put the mass, for example here.
Because then it falls in this rectangle R2, so it contributes to this log of the probability in R2.
But the Emily also won't put any mass here, cause it's better.
To move it a little bit down.
Because then it counts in the two rectangles are two NR 3.
So you get a larger log likelihood function.
So by reasoning.
In this way you can see that the maximum likelihood estimator can only put mass in these two regions.

And these regions are what I call maximal intersections, because those are the regions where those observation rectangles have maximal overlap and the idea is that if you put mass there then you get maximum contribution to the log likelihood.
No, another property of the Emily is that it doesn't matter if we put the mask.
Here in this point, or if we move it a little bit to the right.
The log likelihood function will have exactly the same value.
So there is a certain non uniqueness in the Emily.
An the best we can do is estimate how much mass we put in each of the regions, but we don't know how to distribute it within those regions.

And then when you solve that, will see that A1 should be 1/3.
So here we put mass 1/3 an.
Here we're going to put mass 2/3 and that's the Emily.
So.
From this simple example, it follows that computation of the Emily can be split into 2 steps.
First we need to find these maximal intersections.
The areas where the Emily can put mass.

An I call that a reduction step cause by doing that we reduced this infinite dimensional optimization problem that we had here over a function space to a finite dimensional optimization problem in Alpha.
And then, once we've done that, we need to solve that optimization problem.

If you have N rectangles.

Then the number of maximal intersections will be ordered into the D so that number can quickly grow so.
We need a fast algorithm to find those regions, and then we also need a fast algorithm to solve a high dimensional optimization problem.
OK, so the outline of the rest of my talk is.

They analyzed also.
The time complexity was ordered into the 5th.

An it was based on a very nice idea that they made a connection with graph theory.
You can represent each rectangle by a node and you can connect to nodes.
If the rectangles overlap and then those maximal intersections correspond to maximal cliques in the graph.
So that is what they used.
But the reason why it is slow is that they don't use that.

In about 2001 and I then found a very nice algorithm for a closely related problem, namely dead.
The problem of finding the maximum number of rectangles that have an nonempty intersection.

We want more information.
